nonMonitoredImpact.title: Non-monitored Impact
nonMonitoredImpact.subtitle: These outcomes are natural by-products of the primary impact above, but will not be measured or verified.

landManagementActions.title: Land Management Actions
landManagementActions.subtitle: This is how the project developers are planning to achieve the primary impact.

projects.name: Mt. Sandy

developer.name: Odonata
developer.description: Odonata is a not-for-profit entity supporting biodiversity impact solutions.

steward.name: Ngarrindjeri Tribe
steward.description: The Ngarrindjeri culture is centered around the lower lakes of the Murray River.

projects.shortDescription: This project is restoring and conserving a large area of native grassland in Southern Australia.
projects.longDescription:
The project will see up to 1.3M Biodiversity Offset Units become available via formal accreditation with the South Australian Department of Environment and Water. The unique site comprises a pristine example of shrub and woodlands associated with the RAMSAR recognised Coorong Region, of particular cultural and environmental significance. A comprehensive site management plan will be undertaken in partnership with local indigenous land owners with the ownership of this and eventually passed on to these groups.

This project represents a truly unique offsetting opportunity, in proximity to Adelaide and in a vitally important bioregion.

This property is a rare pocket of wetlands and woodlands located near the township of Menindee South Australia, nestled in between the Coorong national park and Lake Albert.

As one of the few remaining sections of privately owned remnant vegetation in the area, this represents a unique opportunity for long term preservation. The Coorong, Lake Alexandrina and Lake Albert Wetland is an international significant RAMSAR wetland ecosystems at the intersection of the Murray River and Southern Ocean.

This vital habitat comprises a unique mix of both freshwater and saltwater wetlands and coastal woodlands. The Coorong is the heart of the traditional lands of Ngarrindjeri people, who have hunted and camped on the Mt Sandy property for thousands of years.
keyOutcomesActivities: Site accredited as a Specific Environmental Benefit (SEB) site and credits created by the South Australian Department of Environment and Water.
A land management services agreement will be established with a local indigenous group, employing people from the local community.
The site will be managed in accordance with an agreed management plan to reduce weed pressure, improve the biodiversity value of the location and preserve the value of the land in perpetuity.

After 10 years the land will be vetted to Rigney Namawi Pty Ltd (local indigenous traditional owners). Six monthly project updates in the form of videos, blog posts and photographs will be produced for the first 5 years of the project.

actions.name: Reduce pest populations
actions.description: Monitor and reduce the population of foxes, cats, dingos/wild dogs.

actions.name: Prevent any new weeds or pests becoming established
actions.description: Monitor sites for any new weeds or pests. If observed, plan and implement a control program.

actions.name: Eradicate populations of declared weeds
actions.description: Conserving the plant habitats in the area along rivers and streams.

actions.name: Decommission all artificial water sources
actions.description: Identify artificial water sources. Prioritise those close to boundaries and decommission by either blocking inflow or excluding stock with fences.

actions.name: Limit impact from native mammals
actions.description: Determine the carrying capacity for the property and monitor the population to keep the number below carrying capacity.

actions.name: Determine impacts for herbivory on native vegetation
actions.description: Establish a minimum of three fenced exclosures to prevent grazing from herbivores (both native and introduced).

impact.name: Biodiversity
impact.description: Healthy ecosystems and rich biodiversity are fundamental to life on our planet.

impact.name: Soil organic carbon
impact.description: Sequestering carbon in SOC is one way to mitigate climate change.

impact.name: Above ground biomass
impact.description: Increasing all living biomass which is located above the ground.

impact.name: Soil health
impact.description: The capacity of soil to function as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans.

creditClass.name: Australian Biodiversity Units (ABU’s)
creditClass.description:
ABU’s are an Australian Government endorsed biodiversity credit. An individual ABU represents a 1.5m square area of land of significant environmental value that has been placed under a conservation covenant and agreed management plan. The covenant and management plan secure the long term preservation of the site and ensure the biodiversity value is protected in perpetuity. Vegetation types may include forests, grasslands, mallees, saltmarshes, scrubs, shrublands, wetlands, and woodlands. 

ABU’s are an innovative and unique way for organisations to preserve a tangible section of Australia’s unique natural habitat.

projects.name: Andover Farm

developer.name: Wide Open Agriculture
developer.description: Wide Open Agriculture (ASX: WOA) is a Regenerative Food & Farming company.

steward.name: Rob and Carolyn Rex
steward.description: Rob and Carolyn Rex farm and manage this land using the principles of regenerative agriculture.

projects.shortDescription: Andover is a 1787 hectare broadacre cropping and sheep farm near Kojonup in Western Australia’s Wheatbelt.
projects.longDescription:
Andover (1137 Boscabel-Chittinup Road, Boscabel) is a 1787 ha broadacre property producing canola, wheat, barley and sheep. At latitude -33.68065 and longitude 116.97219, it is situated in the Shire of Kojonup on the border of the Shire of West Arthur.

Andover was purchased by the current owners in 2016, with the farm’s long term management being a 3 way partnership between Wide Open Agriculture, local family farmers and impact investors.

Prior to purchase the farm had been conventionally managed for many years, which had resulted in degraded soil that had been leached of nutrients, and devoid of good biology. The creeklines had been degraded by stock grazing, with inundation and rising salinity levels limiting production. Since taking over and transitioning from conventional to regenerative agricultural practises, the Rexs’ have reduced grazing pressure and better managed livestock rotations to rejuvenate perennial pastures. They have introduced multi species cropping to help rebuild soil health and microbial activity, increasing above and below ground diversity. The implementation of no till practices have helped to reduce erosion and soil degredation.

There is a limitation to what the Rexs’ can achieve within their farming system to regenerate the nature zone, or their biodiversity.  They are eager to take this further, but require support to take the next step in their regenerative journey. This is where the creation and registration of Biodiversity Credits can make a great impact to their whole landscape function.
keyOutcomesActivities: The Conservation Covenant protects land for 100 years minimum
Fire management Plan to reduce fire risk
Revegetation to connect and establishment of new nature zones
New fencing and protection of waterways
Control introduced predators and invasive weeds
Financially support a farming family to transition to regenerative practices

landManagementActions.title: Funded activities within the nature zone, this is how the project developers are planning to achieve the primary impact.

actions.name: Fence existing biodiversity
actions.description: Fencing to exclude stock removes grazing pressure from native species and helps the ecosystem to regenerate.

actions.name: Establish and manage fire breaks
actions.description: Fire can be mitigated by creating fire breaks and working with an approved management plan that reduces fuel build up in the vegetation under story.

actions.name: Revegetate to reconnect fragments
actions.description: Reconnecting fragmented vegetation provides a more resilient ecosystem and creates corridors for wildlife to move through.

landManagementActions.title: Flow on impact by supporting a regenerative farmer. Secondary impact as a result of biodiversity credits purchased.

actions.name: Multi species croppings
actions.description: Multi species crops are more efficient at improving the health and resilience of the the soil to pathogens, increasing soil microbial health by promoting above and below ground diversity, and can be grazed as a fodder crop.

actions.name: High density rotational grazing
actions.description: Increased stock density and long recovery periods maximizes grass growth and carbon drawdown into the soil.

actions.name: Perennial pasture
actions.description: Establishing perennial pasture on salt effected, low lying, or marginally productive land increases the agricultural production of the land as well as supporting a more stable year round climate for soil biology.

impact.name: Biodiversity
impact.description: Healthy ecosystems and rich biodiversity are fundamental to life on our planet.

ABU’s are an Australian Government endorsed biodiversity credit. An individual ABU represents a 1.5m square area of land of significant environmental value that has been placed under a conservation covenant and agreed management plan. The covenant and management plan secure the long term preservation of the site and ensure the biodiversity value is protected in perpetuity. Vegetation types may include forests, grasslands, mallees, saltmarshes, scrubs, shrublands, wetlands, and woodlands.

events.title: Credit term begins
events.description: Crediting Term starts at the initial monitoring date.

events.title: Baseline measurement
events.description: Based on historical sampling data from 2017.

events.title: Monitoring
events.description: Two rounds based on historical sampling data from 2018 & 2019.

projects.name: Wilmot Farm
glanceText: Increased soil organic carbon to 4.5% and removed 21,306 tons of CO2e in two years.
Improved co-benefits significantly with Soil Health ranking as excellent, Ecosystem Health as good, and Animal Welfare as excellent.

developer.name: Impact Ag
developer.description: Impact Ag utilises a variety of pathways and partners to measure and monitise natural capital on assets under management or advisory.

steward.name: Wilmot Cattle Co.
steward.description: Wilmot Cattle Company is an innovative, regenerative, grass-fed beef business.

projects.shortDescription: Wilmot Cattle Co currently operates two properties, Wilmot Farm and Woodburn Farm. The two properties operate cooperatively with a mix of breeding, trading, and 100% natural grass finishing enterprises.
projects.longDescription:
Wilmot Farm is located high in the New England Tablelands in Ebor, Australia. At approximately 1,200 meters above sea level, the 1,854 hectare property has an average annual rainfall of 1,200 mm, highly fertile volcanic basalt soils, pristine spring fed, year-round natural waterways, including five waterfalls. It is a unique environment for growing cattle.

Prior to the commencement of Wilmot Cattle Company operations in 2008, the property had been conventionally managed. In 2013, a property transformation began, adopting regenerative and holistic management practices and resulting in significant gains in the overall ecological health of the farm.

Today the property is managed in an intensive rotationally-grazed system with small numbers of large mobs moving across the landscape, mimicking nature, to create ecological change and improve landscape health and biological function. At shovel depth, our soil organic carbon (SOC) has improved from ~2.5% to >4.5%, with a goal of getting it to >6% by 2023.
keyOutcomesActivities: Unique - avoiding double issuance through GIS tracking
Real - GHG impact is quantifiable and verifiable
Measurable - each credit represents one ton of CO2e
Permanent - 25 year period through reversal buffer or covenant
Additional - a new practice adopted from pre-approved list
Leakage - de minimis in agricultural land management

actions.name: Time Controlled Rotational Grazing
actions.description: Since 2013, Wilmot Cattle Co. has implemented time controlled rotational grazing at Wilmot Farm. In order to mirror natural herding behaviors, time controlled rotational grazing optimizes the number of stock in a paddock, matches the grazing period with available pasture, shortens grazing periods in each paddock, and follows these activities by long resting periods to allow the pasture to recover. When managed well, this grazing system increases groundcover, biomass, plant diversity, animal and plant nutrition, soil health, water infiltration and soil organic carbon. A more complete explanation of the science, monitoring tools and management practices is provided below.

actions.name: Decrease Paddock Size
actions.description: Decreased paddock sizes enable effective grazing at a controllable density. Wilmot Farm has adopted a paddock subdivision program with an average paddock size of 25 hectares.

actions.name: Increase Stock Density
actions.description: Carefully managed, high stock densities lead to evenly grazed pastures, nutrient recycling, increases in pasture health and performance by trampling (or recycling) a higher proportion of biomass, and evenly distributing dung and urine (nutrients).

actions.name: Monitor Pasture Growth
actions.description: Accurate measurement of pasture growth (available feed) determines the density of animals and length of time in a paddock.

actions.name: Manage Grazing Periods
actions.description: To ensure effectively implemented grazing practices and management practices records, Wilmot Farm utilizes the online tool Maia Grazing. Maia Grazing uses climatic data and field observations to determine pasture growth and optimal stocking rates, tracks stock movements, and ensures the stocking rate does not exceed the carrying capacity of each paddock.

impact.name: Soil organic carbon
impact.description: Each credit represents one ton of CO2e (1t CO2e) that has been sequestered in the soil.

impact.name: Ecosystem health
impact.description: We rank the ecosystem health based on the Costanza Framework, measuring its ability to maintain  structure (organization) and function (vigor) over time in the face of external stress (resilience).

impact.name: Animal welfare
impact.description: We rank animal welfare based on adherence to national animal welfare standards that track nutrition level, access to water, social contact and more.

impact.name: Soil health
impact.description: We rank the soil health based on Cornell University’s Soil Health Assessment looking at both micronutrients and macronutrients.

creditClass.name: Carbon Plus Grasslands (beta)
creditClass.description:
Livestock grazing covers over 3.3 billion hectares, or 25 percent of the world’s land area. Managed grazing practices can reverse land degradation, enhance net carbon sequestration, and improve soil and vegetation quality.

Under managed grazing, carbon sequestration potential is estimated between 16.4 and 26 Gt CO2e sequestered in the period between 2020-2050.

This credit is designed to significantly increase the amount of hectares under managed grazing worldwide. To that end, the methodology relies on remote sensing to substantially reduce the cost of monitoring carbon sequestration while maintaining scientific rigor.
